org.apache.flex.utils

Class CheapArray

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.flex.utils.CheapArray

  • public class CheapArray
extends Object
    A set of functions for managing Arrays of Objects in a memory efficient way. This class is a memory-efficient alternative to using ArrayList to manage an array of objects. It is applicable when you have a List that is initially populated with some items, and then lives for a long time without any further changes. Usage: Instead of this ArrayList-based code: // Populate the array List array = new ArrayList(n); array.add(item1); array.add(item2); // Use the data s = array.size(); item = array.get(i); you can use this CheapArray-based code // Populate the array Object array = CheapArray.create(n); CheapArray.add(item1, array); CheapArray.add(item2, array); array = CheapArray.optimize(Object, new MyItemType[0]); // Use the data s = CheapArray.size(array); item = CheapArray.get(i, array); The code for List is cleaner, but there is a benefit to using CheapArray. The difference between CheapArray and ArrayList is this: each time you use ArrayList, you get two java objects: the ArrayList, and the Object[] that it contains. Each ArrayList object occupies 24 bytes of memory. A CheapArray, on the other hand, is typed as Object, and is represented by an ArrayList while the array is being populated, and as an Object[] thereafter. The 24 byte overhead is only incurred transiently, while the array is being populated; the long-term memory cost is for the Object[] only. For convenience, we will use the term "cheapArray" to refer to Objects that are returned by create() and optimize(), even though they are not technically instances of CheapArray. Not keeping the ArrayList object around gives a significant memory usage improvement. As of May 2006, the codemodel tree for a medium size test application (doradoSmall), plus the codemodel tree for the Flex framework (frameworks.swc) had almost 8 megabytes of ArrayList objects. By converting a few key data structures (in NodeBase and its subclasses) to use CheapArray instead of ArrayList, most of that 8 mb of usage has been eliminated.

    • Method Detail

      • create

        public static Object create(int initialCapacity)
        Create a new cheapArray. Use instead of "new ArrayList(initialCapacity)".
        Parameters:
        initialCapacity - the initial capacity of the cheapArray.
        Returns:
        a 'cheapArray' Object that you can use as the "array" parameter in calls to other CheapArray functions.

      • toArray

        public static Object[] toArray(Object array,
               Object[] emptyArray)
        Fetch the contents of a cheapArray. Use instead of List.toArray().
        Parameters:
        array - a cheapArray
        emptyArray - a zero-length array. The array returned by this function will be the same runtime type as this parameter.
        Returns:
        an array containing all the items of the cheapArray.

      • size

        public static int size(Object array)
        Get the number of items of a cheapArray. Use instead of List.size().
        Parameters:
        array - a cheapArray
        Returns:
        the number of items

      • get

        public static Object get(int i,
         Object array)
        Get a particular item from a cheapArray. Use instead of List.get().
        Parameters:
        i - the item's index
        array - a cheapArray
        Returns:
        the specified item

      • add

        public static void add(Object item,
       Object array)
        Adds an item to a cheapArray. This is only allowed before the array is optimized. Use instead of List.add().
        Parameters:
        item - the item to add
        array - a cheapArray

        Comparator comparator)
        Sorts the given array based on a comparator
        Parameters:

      • add

        public static Object add(Object item,
         Object array,
         Object[] emptyArray)
        Adds an item to a cheapArray. This can be used either before or after the array is optimized. Use instead of List.add().
        Parameters:
        item - the item to add
        array - a cheapArray
        Returns:
        a new 'cheapArray' Object that replaces the old instance

      • remove

        public static Object remove(Object item,
            Object array,

        Remove an item from a cheapArray. This can be used either before or after the array is optimized. Use instead of List.remove().
        Parameters:
        item - the item to remove
        array - a cheapArray

      • optimize

        public static Object optimize(Object array,
              Object[] emptyArray)
        Optimize the cheapArray so it uses the minimum possible memory. Use this after the array has been populated with all of its data. After this call, you cannot use add() or remove() on the cheapArray. Use instead of ArrayList.trimToSize().
        Parameters:
        array - a cheapArray
        emptyArray - a zero-length array. The array returned by this function will be the same runtime type as this parameter.
        Returns:
        a 'cheapArray' Object that you can use as the "array" parameter in calls to CheapArray functions.
